Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide partial support for participants to a research conference in San Diego, California from June 17 to June 20, 2019 entitled "Future Directions in Algebraic Combinatorics". This conference will bring together leaders from related fields and a diverse group of younger researchers in order to identify and prioritize goals for future work and to inspire new collaborations for fulfilling these goals. To accomplish this, the conference will be comprised of a dozen in depth talks by experts in various fields, "lightning talks" to propose future work, discussions of priorities by all participants, and a poster session for graduate students and early career attendees.

The goal of this conference is to communicate future goals in symmetric function theory and algebraic combinatorics. Algebraic combinatorics has been at the center of new developments across several fields, including representation theory, algebraic geometry, and topology. Confirmed speakers include leading experts in all aspects of algebraic combinatorics: Franois Bergeron, Sara Billey, Anders Bjorner, Persi Diaconis, Ron Graham, Mark Haiman, Jim Haglund, Claudia Malvenuto, Anton Mellit, Jennifer Morse, Claudio Procesi, Richard Stanley, Dennis Stanton, Michelle Wachs, Nolan Wallach, and Greg Warrington. Additional information is available at the conference website at https://sites.google.com/view/garsiafest/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The conference Future Directions in Algebraic Combinatorics was held June 17-20, 2019 at the Scripps Seaside Forum in San Diego, California. The purpose of this conference was to highlight recent advances and identify promising directions for future study in the field of algebraic combinatorics.

Algebraic combinatorics has been at the center of new developments across several fields, including representation theory, algebraic geometry, and topology. This conference brought together leaders from related fields and a diverse group of younger researchers in order to identify and prioritize goals for future work and to inspire new collaborations for fulfilling these goals. To accomplish this, the conference consisted of 17 in depth talks by experts in various fields, 16 “lightning talks” by early career participants, and several hours of unstructured time each day for collaboration and networking. 

The slides and videos for the conference talks are available to the public at https://sites.google.com/view/garsiafest/talk-video-and-slides

In total, there were 88 participants. A survey was sent to all participants one year after the fact, and about half responded. The survey found that at least 8 participants began new research collaborations at this conference, and over 75% of respondents said that the conference had a positive impact on their existing research. Several participants mentioned that the conference also had a direct, positive influence on their search to find a job / to hire a new faculty member in their department. Over 80% of respondents said that this was one of the best conferences that they had attended recently.

A wide range of mathematicians benefitted from this conference. Over 70% of the survey respondents were early career mathematicians (within 5 years of receiving a PhD at the time of the conference) and over 60% identified as a member of a group which is underrepresented in mathematics. Several of these participants received funding through the conference's NSF grant.
